name: guzheng
definition: The guzheng, also known as Chinese zither, is a Chinese traditional plucked musical string instrument.
description:
Guzheng is a Chinese plucked board zither roughly 120 cm long and 30 cm wide. Its resonator is galley-shaped, and in cross section the top is curved and the bottom flat.

The strings are stretched over the surface, fastened at the left end and at the right where there are pegs for tuning.

A moveable bridge under each of the strings can also adjust the string’s pitch. The modern guzheng usually has 21 strings.

Present-day strings are metal, although they were probably silk in ancient times.

It is played with both hands. Right hand is for strings plucking whereas left hand is used for ornamentations and pitch alterations.

Guzheng players often wear fingerpicks, made from materials such as ivory, tortoiseshell, resin or hard plastic, on one or both hands.

The zheng was used in folk music ensembles or local operas. In the XX-th century it has gradually become a solo musical instrument.

featured.caption:
Moveable bridges are an alternative way to adjust the pitch of the strings.

They are kept in position on the board surface by string tension.

facts.name: Strings made of silk
facts.value: Strings, once made of silk, are almost always steel coated in nylon to increase the instrument's volume and changing its timbre.

facts.name: Made from wutong wood
facts.value: It has a large, resonant cavity made from wutong wood. Other components are often made from other woods for structural or decorative reasons.

facts.name: Ancestor to other Asian zithers
facts.value: The guzheng is ancestor to several other Asian zithers, such as the Japanese koto, the Korean gayageum, Mongolian yatga, and the Vietnamese đàn tranh.

facts.name: Right hand for string plucking
facts.value: In performance the zheng is placed on a table or rack in front of the player, who plucks the strings to the right of the bridges using the first three or four fingers of the right hand.

facts.name: Formal ways to play guzheng
facts.value: There are many formalities used in the playing of the guzheng, including basic plucking actions at the right portion and pressing actions at the left portion, as well as tremolo.

facts.name: Decorated with unique artistic content
facts.value: The guzheng is often decorated with unique cultural and artistic content. Decorations include carved art, carved lacquer, straw, mother-of-pearl inlays, painting, poetry, calligraphy, shell carving, and cloisonné.

facts.name: Left hand for pitch alteration
facts.value: Ornamentations and pitch alterations are created by pressing on the strings to the left of the bridges with the fingers of the left hand.

facts.name: Guzheng is not guqin
facts.value: The guzheng should not be confused with the guqin, a Chinese zither with 7 strings played without moveable bridges.

facts.name: Many changes during its long history
facts.value: The guzheng has gone through many changes during its long history. The oldest specimen yet discovered held 13 strings and was dated to around 500 BCE.

facts.name: Became prominent in Qin
facts.value: It became prominent during the Qin Dynasty (221–206 BCE), and by the Tang Dynasty (618–907 CE), the guzheng may have been the most commonly played instrument in China.
